origin_history: Found dying plant by a dumpster on December 7, 2025.
whats_been_logged: The focus has shifted from rescue recovery into supporting active bud development and flowering, maintaining stable moisture in the 2-gallon container, and monitoring pH drift toward acidic conditions to keep nutrient uptake efficient. Deadheading and bloom-cycle support have become the primary ongoing care priorities.
current_state: The plant is vigorous and actively flowering, with a full, leafy canopy and multiple buds at varying stages of development alongside several open blooms. Stems are upright and structurally sound with no visible wilt or collapse, and foliage is healthy green. Blooms and buds show reddish-bronze tones on petals and bracts under strong sun exposure, consistent with current flowering conditions and possible temperature/light influence.

timeline.what_i_should_see: Deadheading Response and Continued Bloom Cycling

journal.conditions: Sunny with a high of 83°F dropping to 59°F overnight.
journal.observations: The chrysanthemum remains vigorous and actively flowering with multiple open blooms and many buds still developing throughout the canopy. Stems are upright and structurally sound with healthy green foliage and no visible wilting. The soil surface appears dry and the late-afternoon probe reading confirms the container is drying down while the root zone is warm.
journal.actions: Water tomorrow morning with 3 cups of water poured slowly around the pot edge to rehydrate evenly. Mix Purived 4-5-5 at 1 capful per 1 gallon of water and apply 3 cups of the mixed solution as a light feed to support buds and blooms. Deadhead spent blooms by snipping just below the flower head to encourage continued bud opening.
journal.next_steps: Recheck probe readings tomorrow afternoon after watering. Continue watering only when moisture drops to 35.00 or lower, ideally in the morning. Monitor bloom longevity and bud progression; hot late-afternoon soil temperature and low fertility can speed bloom decline if moisture is allowed to drop too far.

photos.caption: Overhead view showing a full canopy with multiple open blooms and many buds still developing, with the soil surface appearing dry across the container.
photos.tags: chrysanthemum, overhead, canopy, buds, blooms, dry-soil

photos.caption: Close view of the soil surface and lower stems showing a dry top layer with perlite visible and bud clusters forming near the base.
Angled view showing multiple open blooms with reddish-bronze tones and many unopened buds tucked through the foliage.
Front view showing upright stems, active flowering, and continued bud production across the upper canopy.
Full pot view showing strong overall form, multiple open blooms around the edges, and dense bud development indicating an ongoing bloom wave.
photos.tags: chrysanthemum, full-plant, pot, blooms, buds, vigor

journal.conditions: Sunny with a high of 82°F dropping to 60°F overnight.
journal.observations: The chrysanthemum remains vigorous and actively flowering with a full canopy, multiple buds, and several open blooms showing reddish and yellow tones. Stems are upright and structurally sound with no visible wilting. The soil surface appears moist but no longer saturated, and overall plant condition remains stable and healthy.
journal.actions: Do not water tomorrow morning; moisture remains comfortably high and continued dry-down supports strong root oxygen exchange. Do not fertilize today as nutrient levels are adequate for flowering. Continue providing strong sun and airflow.
journal.next_steps: Recheck probe readings tomorrow if possible. Resume watering only when moisture drops to 45.00 or lower, ideally in the morning. Continue monitoring for any increase in leaf-edge browning or any bloom decline if soil stays too wet.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Discussed whether to water at 6:00 AM tomorrow; recommended skipping because moisture is still 59.00 and the plant benefits from continued dry-down.

photos.caption: Overhead view showing a dense canopy with multiple buds and several open blooms, with soil appearing moist but not saturated.
Closer view highlighting an open bloom and multiple buds at different stages with healthy green foliage.
Front view showing an open bloom and developing bud clusters with upright stems and stable structure.
Angled view showing multiple open blooms around the pot edge and an abundance of buds preparing to open.
Side view showing the overall form of the plant with many bud clusters and continued flowering activity.

journal.conditions: Sunny with a high of 80°F dropping to 58°F overnight.
journal.observations: The chrysanthemum remains vigorous and actively flowering with a full canopy, multiple buds, and several open blooms showing reddish-bronze tones. Stems are upright and the plant appears stable with no visible wilting. Soil moisture remains high but has improved from the prior day’s saturation, supporting better root-zone oxygen exchange.
journal.actions: Do not water tomorrow morning; moisture remains high and the root zone benefits more from continued dry-down. Do not fertilize today as nutrient levels are sufficient for flowering. Deadhead spent blooms to encourage continued bud opening and maintain bloom cycle momentum.
journal.next_steps: Recheck probe readings tomorrow afternoon if possible. Resume watering only when moisture drops to 45.00 or lower, ideally in the morning. Continue monitoring for any expansion of leaf-edge browning while soil dries down and maintain strong sun exposure.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Discussed whether to water at 6:00 AM tomorrow; recommended skipping due to moisture still reading high (80.00) and the need for continued dry-down for root oxygen.

photos.caption: Top-down view showing a dense, healthy canopy with multiple developing buds and ongoing flowering activity.
Side view highlighting upright stems, multiple buds at different stages, and blooms with reddish-bronze tones under strong sun.
Angled view showing overall plant structure and continued flowering with stable foliage and no visible wilt.

journal.conditions: Sunny with a high of 81°F dropping to 58°F overnight.
journal.observations: The chrysanthemum remains vigorous and actively flowering with multiple buds and open blooms across the canopy. Foliage is generally healthy green with minor browning visible along the edge of at least one leaf, consistent with mild stress rather than widespread decline. The soil appears very wet and the probe indicates saturated moisture, suggesting the root zone is holding more water than needed.
journal.actions: Do not water tomorrow morning; moisture is saturated and the root zone needs to dry down for oxygen exchange. Do not fertilize today as nutrient levels are sufficient for flowering. Deadhead spent blooms to encourage continued bud opening and snip any leaf that is more than 25% browned or crispy.
journal.next_steps: Recheck probe readings tomorrow afternoon. Resume watering only when moisture drops to 45.00 or lower and avoid returning to daily watering. Continue monitoring leaf edges for expansion of browning; if it increases while moisture remains high, prioritize dry-down and airflow.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Discussed whether to water tomorrow morning; recommended skipping due to saturated moisture and the inability to check readings until midday. Discussed whether to snip a leaf with brown edges; advised removing it only if more than 25% damaged or if browning is spreading.

photos.caption: Top-down view showing a full canopy with multiple buds and open blooms, with soil appearing very dark and wet across the pot surface.
Angled view showing several open blooms and numerous buds at different stages, with dense foliage and upright stems.
Side view highlighting bloom clusters and bud development with good overall vigor and no visible wilting.
Alternate angle showing the plant’s overall form and flowering progression, with the potting surface still appearing saturated.

journal.conditions: Sunny with a high of 80°F dropping to 62°F overnight.
journal.observations: The chrysanthemum is actively flowering with multiple buds and several blooms opening, showing reddish-bronze tones on petals and bracts under strong sun exposure. Foliage is green and full with upright stems and no visible wilt or collapse. The plant appears stable and vigorous in the 2-gallon pot with healthy canopy density.
journal.actions: Do not water today as moisture is already ideal. Do not fertilize today; nutrient level is sufficient for bloom support without forcing soft growth. Deadhead spent blooms by snipping just below the flower head to encourage continued bud development.
journal.next_steps: Recheck probe readings in 2–3 days, focusing on pH stability. If pH remains below 5.80, apply 1 tablespoon of dolomite lime evenly across the soil surface and water in with 1 cup only if moisture has dropped. Water only if moisture drops to 35.00 or lower.

photos.caption: Top-down view showing a full, healthy canopy with multiple developing buds and an actively opening bloom with reddish-bronze coloration.
Angled side view showing a dense, vigorous plant structure with upright stems, multiple bud sites, and several blooms opening at the outer edges.

journal.conditions: Sunny with a high of 82°F dropping to 66°F overnight.
journal.observations: The chrysanthemum is firmly in active bud development with numerous uniform buds across all stems. Buds are tight and well formed with some reddish or bronze blush on outer bracts, consistent with early-stage yellow chrysanthemum development under high light. Foliage remains turgid and stems are structurally sound.
journal.actions: No watering today; soil moisture is adequate and watering would risk overnight saturation. No fertilization applied; fertility level supports bud expansion without forcing soft growth.
journal.next_steps: Recheck probe readings at the next opportunity. Monitor buds for swelling and initial petal separation as flowering approaches. Continue current sun exposure and airflow.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Confirmed that bud coloration is consistent with a single yellow chrysanthemum cultivar; early reddish tones are normal and will fade as petals emerge.

photos.caption: Top-down view showing uniform bud distribution and strong canopy structure.
Side view highlighting firm stems and synchronized bud development.
Close-up of immature bud showing normal reddish blush prior to yellow petal emergence.
Close-up showing multiple compact buds at different nodes.
Detail view of foliage and buds under full sun conditions.

journal.conditions: Patchy fog before 8 AM, otherwise partly sunny with a high near 84°F dropping to around 61°F overnight.
journal.observations: The chrysanthemum shows strong continued recovery with sturdy, turgid foliage and many newly visible bud sites developing across multiple stems. Structure remains upright and stable, and bud clusters are becoming more defined, indicating active progression toward flowering.
journal.actions: Do not water tonight as moisture remains adequate and nighttime watering would increase saturation risk. Do not fertilize today; nutrient levels are appropriate for bud development. Recheck moisture tomorrow morning and water only if the reading drops to 35.00 or lower.
journal.next_steps: Recheck probe readings tomorrow morning. Monitor pH over the next few days to ensure it does not continue drifting downward. Watch bud clusters for uniform swelling and color development as flowering approaches.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Discussed whether the new buds will all be the same color; explained they should bloom consistently yellow if this is a single cultivar, with minor early-bloom variation possible during recovery.

photos.caption: Top-down view showing multiple developing bud clusters and healthy, turgid foliage across the pot.
Side view highlighting upright stems, expanding leaves, and numerous newly forming buds along the stem tips.

journal.conditions: Partly sunny with a high of 83°F dropping to 67°F overnight.
journal.observations: The chrysanthemum shows clear advancement into vegetative refill with increased leaf size, paired leaf expansion on multiple stems, and well-defined but compact bud sites. Foliage remains healthy and upright following several hours of intermittent rain. Soil is evenly moist and settled with no signs of pooling or stress.
journal.actions: Do not water today as soil moisture is sufficient from rainfall. Do not fertilize; nutrient availability is adequate and active. Leave soil undisturbed to allow pH and moisture to stabilize naturally.
journal.next_steps: Recheck soil readings in 1–2 days after the soil equilibrates. Monitor pH for a natural return toward the mid-6 range. Continue observing bud behavior to ensure slow, controlled development.

photos.caption: Top-down view showing increased leaf density and multiple compact bud sites after rainfall.
Side view highlighting paired leaf expansion and upright stems with no rain-related stress.
Alternate angle showing evenly settled, moist soil and balanced regrowth across the pot.

journal.conditions: Mostly sunny with a high near 80°F dropping to around 65°F overnight.
journal.observations: The chrysanthemum continues active recovery with firm, upright stems and increasing leaf mass at multiple nodes. Bud sites are present but remain compact, which is appropriate for this stage. Surface soil showed wind-related crusting prior to loosening, but overall soil structure remains stable with no signs of stress or water imbalance.
journal.actions: Do not water today as moisture is ideal and rainfall is expected. Do not fertilize; nutrient levels are well matched to the plant’s recovery stage. Avoid deep soil disturbance and maintain current placement.
journal.next_steps: Allow rain to naturally rehydrate and settle the surface. Recheck soil moisture within 24–48 hours. Continue monitoring for paired leaf expansion as confirmation of vegetative refill progression.

photos.caption: Top-down view showing expanding leaf mass and evenly distributed regrowth after wind exposure.
Side view highlighting upright stems, compact bud sites, and healthy leaf expansion.
Alternate angle showing stable soil surface after light fluffing and balanced regrowth.

journal.conditions: A 20 percent chance of showers and thunderstorms, partly sunny with a high of 81°F dropping to 63°F overnight.
journal.observations: The chrysanthemum is actively rebuilding its canopy with multiple stems elongating and producing larger, well-formed leaves. Bud sites are present but remain juvenile, which is appropriate at this stage. Stems are firm and upright with no signs of wilt, stress, or disease, and soil structure appears stable and evenly settled.
journal.actions: Do not water today as moisture is ideal and rain chances are sufficient. Do not fertilize; existing nutrient levels are appropriate for continued vegetative recovery. Leave soil undisturbed and maintain current placement.
journal.next_steps: Recheck soil moisture in 24–48 hours after weather passes. Monitor for paired leaf expansion across multiple stems as confirmation of full vegetative refill. Continue observing bud behavior without intervention.

photos.caption: Top-down view showing active canopy rebuild with multiple stems producing expanding leaves.
Angled side view highlighting upright stems, healthy internode spacing, and early bud sites.
Alternate angle showing balanced regrowth across the pot and stable soil surface.

journal.conditions: Mostly sunny with a high of 79°F dropping to 62°F overnight.
journal.observations: The plant shows healthy shoot recovery with some continued expansion and increased leaf definition. The stems remain firm, and the plant appears stable. There's even growth across the pot, but some areas at the base are still a bit slower to recover. Soil moisture is high, but no signs of stress yet.
journal.actions: No watering required today. Avoid further fertilization due to adequate slow-release nutrients. Maintain current light exposure. Pot rotation is still advised for even growth distribution.
journal.next_steps: Monitor moisture tomorrow morning. Watch for continued expansion and leaf development, particularly from the slower areas at the base. Maintain current care plan.

photos.caption: Top-down view showing even recovery and new growth across the pot.
Side view highlighting thickening stems and improved foliage.

journal.conditions: Mostly Sunny with a high of 73°F dropping to 53°F overnight.
journal.observations: The plant continues strong early shoot recovery with thicker, more structured new growth across all stems. Leaf shape is becoming more defined, and growth is evenly distributed throughout the pot. Bud primordia are visible but not advancing, which is appropriate for this stage. Soil structure remains stable with no signs of compaction returning.
journal.actions: No watering required as moisture levels are ideal. No fertilization applied; slow-release pellets remain active. Soil left undisturbed to allow continued root establishment. Pot rotated slightly for even light exposure.
journal.next_steps: Continue daily visual monitoring. Recheck moisture tomorrow morning. Watch for paired leaf expansion on multiple shoots as the indicator of approaching transition into vegetative refill.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Confirmed that current temperatures are ideal for chrysanthemum recovery and not a concern.

photos.caption: Top-down view showing even early shoot recovery across the pot.
Side view highlighting thickening stems and emerging leaf structure.
Alternate angle showing uniform growth and stable soil surface.
Close view of developing leaves and early bud sites.
Full pot view showing balanced regrowth after pruning.

journal.conditions: Mostly Sunny with a high of 77°F dropping to 52°F overnight.
journal.observations: The plant shows strong early shoot recovery with multiple stems pushing new foliage and buds. Leaf color is brighter and more uniform than previous days, and the center crown is now activating with new shoots. The soil surface has improved structure from the loosened root layer and added potting mix, allowing deeper probe contact. No signs of wilt, rot, or fungal issues are present.
journal.actions: Do not water today as moisture is ideal for cool conditions. Avoid fertilizing, since nutrient availability remains sufficient from the existing slow-release pellets. Leave the soil undisturbed to allow the root zone to stabilize. Rotate the pot slightly to promote even light exposure across emerging shoots.
journal.next_steps: Recheck soil moisture tomorrow morning. Monitor new shoots for leaf-pair development, which will signal the transition toward vegetative refill. Expect noticeable canopy thickening over the next few days under the favorable cool and sunny weather pattern.

photos.caption: Morning probe reading showing balanced pH, moisture, and nutrient levels.
Top-down view showing active early shoot recovery and brightened foliage.
Side angle view with multiple stems producing new shoots and improved leaf color.

journal.conditions: Slight Chance T-storms then Showers Likely with a high of 83°F dropping to 63°F overnight.
journal.observations: The plant shows active recovery with fresh shoots expanding along the stems and improved leaf color. The soil beneath the hardened surface layer contained dense roots and intact slow-release fertilizer pellets, which were exposed during loosening. Moisture distribution is now more even, and the overall structure appears healthier following the addition of fresh potting mix. No signs of rot or disease are visible.
journal.actions: Leave the exposed slow-release pellets in place. Do not fertilize today, as nutrient levels remain adequate. Avoid further soil disturbance to allow roots to settle from the deep loosening. Do not water, since moisture is ideal and conditions are humid with rain likely.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture tomorrow morning to confirm stable hydration. Monitor pH over the next several days as the loosened soil and existing pellets equilibrate. Watch for rapid shoot expansion and fuller leaf development as the plant continues its recovery.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Confirmed that the metallic green balls uncovered in the soil are slow-release fertilizer pellets and are safe to leave in place.

photos.caption: Close-up of loosened soil showing slow-release fertilizer pellets and fine root mat.
Top-down view of the recovering chrysanthemum showing new shoot growth after soil loosening.
Detailed view of emerging foliage and healthy green shoots developing along pruned stems.

journal.conditions: Slight Chance T-storms then Showers Likely with a high of 83°F dropping to 63°F overnight.
journal.observations: The plant shows strong recovery potential with fresh green shoots emerging along the stems after a hard prune. The remaining foliage is soft but viable, and stems appear healthy with no signs of rot. The probe encountered difficulty entering the top layer due to a dense mat of surface roots, which is typical of a severely root-bound chrysanthemum. Soil pH is highly alkaline at 8.39, which may limit nutrient uptake.
journal.actions: Gently loosen the top half inch of soil to break the dense root crust and improve air and water movement. Apply a light quarter-inch layer of Miracle-Gro Organic Potting Mix across the surface to introduce organic matter and help buffer pH downward. Do not water today, as moisture is ideal and expected rainfall will supply hydration.
journal.next_steps: Recheck soil readings tomorrow after the rain to evaluate pH movement and moisture changes. Monitor new shoot development and avoid fertilizing until pH moves closer to neutral. Maintain bright light exposure but avoid harsh afternoon sun until fuller leaf regrowth occurs.

photos.caption: Before photo showing the chrysanthemum with extensive browning and spent blooms prior to pruning.
After photo showing the plant post-pruning with visible new green shoots emerging.
After photo highlighting the remaining stems and early shoot development from the crown.
